titleStmt.title: Parla-CLARIN: a TEI schema for parliamentary debates
titleStmt.author: Tomaž Erjavec, tomaz.erjavec@ijs.si
Andrej Pančur, andrej.pancur@inz.si

availability.p: This file is freely available and you are hereby authorised to copy, modify, and redistribute it in any way without further reference or permissions.

projectDesc.p: Research Infrastructure for Language Resources and Tools CLARIN.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Corpora of parliamentary proceedings are a quintessential resource for a wide range of research questions from a number of SSH disciplines, such as critical discourse analysis, history, as well as Sociolinguistics. Their most distinguishing characteristic is that they are transcriptions of spoken language produced in controlled and regulated circumstances. For this reason, they are rich in invaluable (sociodemographic) metadata as well as easily available under the Freedom of Information Acts set in place to enable informed participation by the public and to improve effective functioning of democratic systems, making the datasets even more valuable.

Given these reasons and the fact that parliamentary proceedings are more and more often avaliable on-line, many researchers have already compiled corpora of parliamentary proceedings. However, these corpora are encoded in a variety of different annotation schemes, limiting their interchange and re-use.

In order to overcome this problem, the presented recommendation proposes a schema that can be used for encoding of corpora of parliamentary proceedings, primarily for the purposes of scholarly investigations, and that could serve as a storage and interchange format for such corpora. This recommendations attempts to take into account the following aspects of corpora parliamentary proceedings:
Structure: legislative periods, sessions, topics, speeches
Metadata: mandates, titles, parliamentary bodies, location, date and time
Speakers: age, party membership, links to external resources
Political parties: name(s), history
Speeches: speaker, text, comments, verbal and non-verbal interruptions
Text versions: verbatim or redacted records
Multimedia: audio and video, facsimile of original
Linguistic annotation: PoS tagging, normalisation, syntax
Legislative aspects: specification of laws, roll-calls
The recommendation is implemented as a parametrisation of the TEI Guidelines, ...
The rest of these guidelines are structured as follows...

div.head: Scope and purpose of the recommendation
div.p: This recommendation consists of guidelines and a formal TEI and XML schema and is intended for the encoding of corpora of parliamentary debates, regardless of the langauge or country of origin, for the purposes of scholarly investigations, be they from the field of linguistics, political science, history or other humanities and social sciences disciplines. The recommendation is not meant as the primary storage format of parliamentary debates, such as kept by govermental offices, for which Akomo Ntoso is preferred.

In developing a schema for structuring of data, two approaches can be adopted, either a descriptive one, whereby as much as possible of the original data distinctions are kept in the target encoding, and the perscriptive one, where the target encoding is severly constrained, to enable seamless data interchange and esp. interoperability with software tools. The present recommendation adopts the descriptive approach, as the source data, time and effort devoted to converting it, the intended applications, as well as country-specific rules of parliamentary debates will differ considerably, and it is likely that any perscriptive schema would soon turn out to be too restrictive. Nevertheless, the recommendation does try to limit the plethora of encoding options otherwise available in TEI to those that could be sensibly applied to corpora of parliamentary debates, and where more than one option is available in TEI to encode a given phenomenon, the descriptive guidelines or the schema attempt to allow only one option.

div.head: CLARIN and parliamentary proceedings
div.p:
The CLARIN European Research Infrastructure for Language Resources and Technology has already organised a number of initatives and events that deal with parliamentary corpora:
CLARIN-PLUS cross-disciplinary workshop Working with parliamentary records, Sofia 2017
CLARIN Resource Families Parliamentary corpora, 2018-2019
ParlaCLARIN workshop at LREC 2018
CLARIN Annual Conference, Pisa 2018: Work on proposal for COST Action Parlant: "Parliamentary Data and Language Technology" (proposers Maciej Ogrodniczuk, Petya Osenova)
At these events it became clear that existing parliamentary corpora are encoded in many different way, presenting a barrier to their interchange. Therefore the CLARIN Interoperability Committee organised a focused CLARIN ParlaFormat workshop (May 23-24, 2019, Amersfoort) with selected participants at which the idea of the present recommendation was introduced, the participants presented their own experiences with encoding parliamentary corpora and their comments to the draft proposal, and the authors of the proposal gave responses to these comments. The details are given in the slides of the workshop.

div.head: Akoma Ntoso
div.p: Akoma Ntoso is a

div.head: Characters
div.p: A Parla-CLARIN corpus should, in general, capture as much of the text and markup from the source as possble, while the presence of graphical items or other elements that could not or were not transcribed should be indicated by markup, in particular with the use of gap.

The corpus should be encoded in Unicode, using the UTF-8 character encoding, at least for European languages. In cases where the original contains characters from the Unicode Private Use Area, these should be either given their closest equivalents, or, preferably, be appropriatelly marked up by the use of the g element.
End-of-line hyphens can be removed, and the split words joined in order to simplify linguistic processing.

Two characters, esp. prevalent when the source documents are in Word, deserve special mention:
Non-breaking pace (U+00A0), which prevents, with some applications, collapsing consecutive white space characters into a single space. As TEI-Parla is not interested in preserving the details of the layout, it is recommended that this character is substituted by the regular space (U+0020).
Soft hyphen (U+00AD), which indicates that a word can be hyphenated at that point. These characters should be removed from the corpus, as they only complicate further processing.

While not required, it is sensible to also normalise sequences of whitespace characters (such as tabulators, end-of-line characters and spaces) into a single space or end-of-line character. Again, this simplifies further (esp. linguistic) processing.

div.head: Documenting the encoding process
div.p:
Difficult encoding situations that are not covered by the TEI Guidelines should be documented in the editorialDecl of the corpus TEI header.
In particular, if the source texts has been changed (so, ommitting or normalising figures, text, EOL hyphens, special characters, etc. as discussed above) this practice should be documented in the correction and normalization elements of the editorial declaration.

div.head: Languages
div.p: The language of an element's text content is in TEI, as in XML, signaled by the value of its xml:lang attribute. The Parla-CLARIN recommendation requires that the root element of the corpus should have an xml:lang attribute, and, furthermore, that each element that contains text is either marked by this attribute, or one of its ancestors is. Note that if, going by the ancestor axis, the values of two xml:lang are in conflict, the one closer to the context node is relevant one.
The values of xml:lang should follow BCP 47, cf. also xml:lang in XML document schemas.
It is good practice to document the languages used in the langUsage element of the TEI header.

Apart from the above considerations, a related question is where to draw the line between the object and meta languages, i.e. the language of the corpus and the language of the mark-up. The TEI defines the names of the elements and attributes in English, and the language of the corpus will, of course, depend on the country of the parliament. It is less clear in which language the names of the attribute values should be. Parla-CLARIN recommends that these should also be in English.

div.head: Identifiers and referencing
div.p: In order to simply refer to elements of a TEI document (i.e. a Parla-CLARIN corpus), these are given an xml:id attribute, as defined by W3C.

Parla-CLARIN requires an xml:id attribute on the root element of each corpus file, which should, furthermore, be identical to the filename (modulo the file extension). Parla-CLARIN also recommends that the divisions of the document (element div) should also be given identifiers. While any element can be given an xml:id, this is in general, not a good idea; rather, only those elements that will be referenced should be marked with this attribute.

TEI offers a number of attributes that contain (URI) pointers. Where the reference is to an element inside the document, the value of the xml:id being referred to should be preceded by a hash (#), as mandated by the XML standard. However, TEI also offers another way of pointing, which can be used to shorten otherwise long URI references, and this is defined by the listPrefixDef element in the TEI header.

div.head: Files
div.p: While this recommendation makes the assumption that a complete corpus is one TEI XML document, this does not mean that it should also be stored in one file, as the file structure is distinct from the concept of XML documents. To enable one XML document to be composed of several files, the XInclude recommendation should be used.
We recommend that the file has the same name as the value of the xml:id attribute of the root element of the file. This e.g. guarantees that each file of the corpus has a unique name.

div.head: Corpus structure
div.p: As illustrated below, a CLARIN-Parla corpus should be rooted in an teiCorpus element, which should also contain the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate language codeFor multilingual documents (excluding cases where only a minor part of the text is in another language), this code would be mul for multiple languages. The teiHeader of the corpus then contains the metadata for the complete corpus, including the metadata that is referred to by the subordinate TEI elements, such as the defined taxonomies and the list of speakers.

We do not specify what an individual TEI element should contain, as the size and granularity of parliamentary debate corpora, not to mention the national rules of structuring the workings of the parliament will differ substantially. Typically, however, and individual TEI element would contain one sitting or session or one day, in any case such data that has common metadata that distinguishes it from the other TEI elements in the corpus.

Finally, although not given in the Figure below, a text element can contain, apart from the body also a front element before it and/or a back element after it. While the body will contain the speeches and is obligatory, the former could contain some preamble text, while the latter various appendices or texts that are related to the speeches

div.head: Text divisions
div.p: In the text body, as well as in the front and back matter, the element that further organises their content is the division, div, and each of the three elements (if present) should contain at least one division.

The divisions can be nested, and are further specified by their type and, possibly, subtype attributes. For the recommended values of type we take as our model the structure elements as defined by Akoma Ntoso. The subtype attribute is to be used for cases where some facets of structures in the source data cannot be otherwise retained in the Parla-CLARIN encoding, i.e. it is used when we do not want to lose some information about the source data structures.

div.head: Speakers
div.p: Unlike some other proposals, in particular Akoma Ntoso, this recommendation assumes that speaker meta-data is also included in the corpusOf course, this does not meant that external links with URIs are not allowed., as this allows the corpus to be stand-alone with all the relevant data necessary for analysis already included in it.

div.head: Transcriptions
div.p: The transcriptions of the speeches are the central part of this recommendation.

div.head: Multimedia
div.p: Parliamentary corpora can also have data from other modalities associated with the transcripts.

div.head: Speech and video
div.p: The transcription can refer to and align with external audio and video data using the timeline element.

div.head: Conversions
div.p: A TEI encoded document is, in general, not meant to be used directly by software programs, rather it serves as an interchange and storage format. Furthermore, most TEI documents are not "born TEI", but rather converted into TEI from some source format. In this section we discuss some up- and down-conversion scripts that have already been developed for transforming source formats into Parla-CLARIN and from Parla-CLARIN into formats immediatelly usable by software.

moduleRef.include: TEI back body div front text docDate

moduleRef.except: alt altGrp bicond binary cond default fDecl fDescr fsConstraints fsDescr fsdDecl fsdLink if iff then vDefault vLabel vMerge vNot vRange

sch:rule.sch:assert: A text division of type should not occur inside div with type value .

valItem.desc: General purpose text division for all parts of a parliamentary debates. This is markup for a generic structural container for all other parts of a debates that are not explicitly supported with the other values of this attribute. It is a good practice to use the @subtype attribute for additional content classification.
General purpose text division for one or more speeches that were not necessarily held in parliament
Parts of a debate relevant to addresses
Parts of a debate containing adjournment notices
Parts of a debate containing the administration of an oath
Parts of a debate containing communications from the house
Parts of a debate relevant to the declaration of votes
Parts of a debate containing written statements by participants
Parts of a debate containing resolutions
Parts of a debate relevant to the notices of motions
Parts of a debate containing oral statements by participants
Parts of a debate relevant to the display of papers
Parts of a debate relevant to petitions
Parts of a debate containing prayers
Parts of a debate relevant to procedural motions
Parts of a debate relevant to points of order
Parts of a debate containing written statements by participants
Parts of a debate relevant to questions
Parts of a debate containing resolutions
Parts of a debate containing a roll call of individuals
Parts of a debate containing written statements by participants
Description in the third person of events taking place in the meeting, e.g. "Mr X. takes the Chair".
Summaries of speeches that are individually not interesting, e.g. "Question put and agreed to".
Name, role and possible description of a person doing the speech
Outcome of a vote
The location of the speaker, who was not on the podium
Date of the session
Chairman of a meeting
Comment of parliamentary reporter
Date and time of the beginning and end of the debate
The presence of the members of parliament
Comments on the conduct of debates
